Another epic bottle shared by darkguardian at Ryans TOSPH.  Cloudy pee colored pour.  Funk and barnyard aromas.  A well balanced geuze with lemon, citrus, and barnyard funk flavors.

Bottle shared at Tower of Sour Power. Cant remember who brought this one. By this time of the  night I pretty much stopped taking notes and just listed what I drank. Did I like it? Yeah I did but I cant recall the super specifics of this one.

(2011 750ml)A geuze orgy of differing beers that marries to make a classy bier .  nose suggests sweaty feet,   cheesey hops..white grapes..tart green apple , shit and barnyard intentions.  In the mouth its mellow at this age ,  sweaty cheese ,must ,brett , notable richness shows up to make this complex ,rounded , very drinkable and pretty excellent.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy apricot color with a nice fluffy white dense head. Nice lace. Peachy, fruity aroma, slightly white wine like. Starts with a nive sourness that then builds to a slight bitterness note. Light mouthfeel. Overall, I was surprised a little at this one, on one hand it is pretty tasty and easy drinking but on the other I find it lacks a certain depth seen in other Lambic. I like it but wish it hand just a little more something to it.

Light golden orange colour, very slight white head. Very floral aroma, fruity apple, apricot, tart notes, lactic acid, old wood, funk. Tart flavour, very smooth though. Fruity, but bit thinner than expected. Finish fruity and tart.
(Bottle @ Café de Beyerd, Breda)

Bottle. Pours light golden orange with dense foamy white head. Aromas are not huge but are really well balanced. Good nose of green apple and grapefruit with lots of earthy barn yard funk. Flavours are almost identical with good acidity and some earthiness. Whilst subtle still quite complex. Very lively prickly carbonation. Liked this one.

Bottle shared at Funk fest tasting, thanks!!  Pour is cloudy golden with a medium white head.  Aroma is quite tart with notes of vanilla, funk, hat, and horse.  Flavor is really very smooth with notes of vanilla, funk, hay, and fruit.  Flavor is really very smooth and great.

Bottle (RBESGG2011, Grand Tasting) - 2011 edition
Nice cloudy orange. Rather dull aroma, has that vague gueuzy fingerprint, but it isnt singing. Lovely sharp palate, and the finish is nice and buttery, and full of woody resins. Very nice bite to it. A pretty good gueuze, but no stunner.
Drank the 2009 and the 2011 ones. 2009 was, at that time, not old enough but already quite complex, will only get better when aging.

750 ml gren corked and caged bottle poured a clear gold with a lasting ivory head. Aromas of straw, lemon and horseblanket. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a tart finish. Flavors of straw, lemon and horseblanket with a crisp dry lightly tart lingering funky finish.

(4.3)Bottle at THE Sour and Saison Tasting, London. Vintage 2011. Thanks to Jack. Pours hazy gold with a lovely, white foam head. Big, fresh grass in the nose. Had this one @ In De Wildeman. 2009 edition. Orange colored brew. Fruity aroma, sour, barn. Flavor has fruits, moderate sourness, smooth. Really nice.

750 ml bottle. Blend 2011, BBE 28.10.2030. No. 03078.
Pours a hazy yellow colour with a white head. Strong, extremely sour aroma of ripe fruits and some citrus with earthiness. Strong acidic flavour of ripe fruits, caramel and lemon. 750 ml botlle, vintage 2009. A hazy/cloudy medium to dark blonde beer, with a huge, fizzy, mostly diminishing white head. The aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately to heavily yeasty (barnyard, mold, cheese, duaty basement), with a note of lemon and green apple. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, heavily acidic. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, dry long finish with light bitterness. Impressive yeasty and funky aroma, average appearence IMHO, but good balance and complexity. Maybe pricey, but very good.

2011 Bottle at RBESG Grand Tasting, held at Dean Swift.
Cheers to Chriso for another great geuze. Pretty golden color, almost pastel. Very funky citrus nose, stank-ass, lemon rind. Really funky and dry nose. Flavor is sweet lemon, though also very sour, lactic, with leather and the ol horse blanket. Nice bland of sour, funk, sweet. Great.

Bottles of the 09 and the 11 provided by Chuck at Glimmerglass prior to BCTC so we could do a side by side.  They pour a hazed amber with some light grey floaties in the 09, and a large white head.  Big funk, wood and brett, the wood being more prominent in the 11.  The 11 is a bit cheesier and funkier, both having nice big funk and wood notes, brett and acid.  Big acid, cheesy funk, malty, funky and nice acid.  More acid on the 09 than the 11, with the 11 tending toward a bit more funk and wood.  Both really nice.

Bottled at In de Wildeman, 2009 version. The aroma has fruits, citrus, some aprikots, horseblanket. Hazy, orange coloured beer with a big white, foamy head. The taste is moderate sour/tart, slight sweet. Citric, very fruity. Quite a lot body for a gueuze and smooth. Very nice one.

I have 6 bottles 0,75l and tasted it @ the tour de geuze 2011.
Very young but nice blend.
Well balanced and sourish taste.
Look forward when it has an age...
Ung och snäll doft. Balanserad stor syrlighet av äpplen. Lagom eftersmak. Syrlig men dog len. Gött-götti-gött-gött!

Thanks to Godofthunder for sharing this!  Mega blend is right.  Tart citrus notes on the nose, musty.  Pours a dark golden color.  Tart citrusy with old wood notes. super funky, sour dry finish.  Amazing to get to try!

Bottled at In de Wildeman, 2009 version. Slight hazy orange golden color, huge rocky head like champagne. And thats one of the first things that come into mind while taking the glass towards the nose: champagne like aromas, grapes, pineapple, slight citrus, mango. A lot of (tropical) fruit so to say, together with the traditional horseblanket and barnyard aroma, but very fruity. Moderate tartness, slight sweet. Not as harsh as some Cantillons, but full bodied and smooth (for a gueuze), champagne-like. Good stuff, but bloody expensive!

2011 Bottle. Pours a nice hazy orange/dark blond color with a frothy white head. Aroma is filled with funk, old musty notes, barnyard, wet hay, vinous notes, white grapes, green apples and vinegar. The flavor is super complex and fairly tart/sour, with lots of funk. I get loads of barnyard, wet hay, green apples, white grapes and other light fruits, white balsamic vinegar, white wine notes and some dusty old notes. The body is medium with a pretty dry mouthfeel. Overal a really good Gueuze, definietly something worth seeking out!

Bottle shared by Ari, thanks! Poured a cloudy/hazy gold with a white head that started and remained at the edges. Aroma had a light horse blanket note with tart to sour fruits and a bit of lemon. Flavor was similar with a nice funk note that worked well with the sour fruits that grew to a slight acidity in the finish.

2011 bottle. Amber gold, rocky white head like a cloud. Old sock, dust, and citrus nose, very musty. Flavor of grapefruit  and dust, lightly bitter in the high carbonation, which isolates and suppresses the flavors, hay and grapefruit emerging in the too dry, too bitter finish. Bottle.

Slightly hazy golden/orange with a nice fluffy head. Very inviting and fresh aroma of green apples, citrus, grass, wood and horse blanket. The taste was also very good, I really liked the sourness of this beer. The aftertaste was not that long.

At the sour tasting, thanks Shahar, gashing, cork shooting, then pours shiny yellow with a gaint head, aroma is acidic with some honey, vanilla, fresh fruits and malt, flavor is fruity with lively carbonation, malt and fresh leaves, almost full bodied, greaqt

M: Medium in body with a very high carbonation.

O: A decent gueuze, but not really amazing, especially for the price/difficulty of acquisition.

2009 bottle thanks to 4.4 40. Chunky reddish pink pour with a thin white head. Horse blanket, vinegar, lightly acidic aroma. Taste is light tart sour lemon, not puckering, but gentle with notes of cherry skin tartness. Not a fave style of mine, but this is light, dry and wonderfully tasty.

750ml, caged and corked, bottle. Poured a cloudy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of funk, grassiness, wood, and citrus. Tastes of the same funkiness, wood, citrus, and barnyard.

Bottle 2009 vintage. Pale straw colored pour with white head. Aroma of classic gueuze funk, stinky feet, light mineral character, wood, lemon peel and floral notes. The 2011 version poured from a bottle at Hanssens lambic blenders. Amber body, slightly hazed. Bubbly white layer. Tart fruity smell. Rounded acid taste profile with refreshing tartness towards the ending. A nice living product, full of charm (Toer de Geuze, Dworp 01.05.2011).

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2011 [2009] Hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of wood, bretts, and nice bacterias, and some citrus, very funky.  Taste of much of the same, with a sour bite in the finish.

2009 bottling, bottle no. 12739, courtesy 4.4-40.  The cork shot out of this puppy like a rocket as soon as the cage was loosened.  The body is a hazy dark golden color.  A thin white film settles in at the head and lasts for the duration of the drink.  Aromas are funky as all hell, showing a strong, pervasive barnyard must all the way from start to finish.  Notes of horseblanket, footy cheese, and musty old basement are distinct.  Dust and old, soured, slightly seasoned wood are too.  Sharp, pithy lemon acidity walks in step with all the must, providing its citric counterpoint.  Flavors follow suit, intensely musty and loaded with aged farmhouse cheese, sourdough bread, and tangy apricots.  Old wet wood and sharp, oily lemon are wonderful compliments.  Dusty brett and sour lacto are both wild and focused at the same time.  Delicious stuff.  This beer just feels ALIVE.....and it is.  The palate is substantial for a gueuze, showing a good amount of smooth malt to counter the spritzy, dusty, drying body.  Awesome stuff.  I should have bought a ton of this stuff when I had the chance.
The 2011 edition. A very nice example of a malse Oude Geuze. A bit more balls would have lifted this one to perfection

pours coudy orange with a slight head. aroma is ver sour and wild. flavour is very sour and complex this is a great lambic. I am really enjoying it. Very sour. great ;ambic.

text: Bright and hazy golden with a finger thick white head. Tart funky nose and flavor. Grapefruit and barnyard with a decent finish.

Best by 16.10.2028; Sampled August 2009
A very careful pour still manages to produce four-fingers of head in my 25cl plus an additional almost two fingers above the rim.  The head is a light tan hue and the beer is a grassy, pale amber hue that shows a nice orange-gold hue and a touch of haze when held up to the light.  Some light, but nice lacing forms on the sides of my glass as the head slowly subsides.  The aroma has a nice grassy funkiness to it that reminds me of a mix of hay, weeds, phenolic soaked cotton, musty damp horse blankets along with a requisite musky, almost dried sweat stench.  The sharper notes in the nose are defined by the lactic acid, a hard urea-laced spicing, some phenolic wild mushroom notes.  The finish has some nice pale grain and fresh crushed wheat character to it.  This is actually on the funky side for a Gueuze, and I must say it is quite nice. 

This beer has a nice, solid, almost bracing lactic sourness.  This finishes with a nice spicy oak note as well as some tannic woody notes, both of which integrate quite well with the other flavors in this beer.  A touch of urea, or cat-pee for the Lambic traditionalist, is found in the flavor.  There are some grassy notes up front and in the middle that are separate from the hint of grain character that is left in this beer (though this seems to contribute some grassiness and a touch of pale grain in the finish; not as much as is found in the nose though).  While this seems bone dry, some of the notes here contribute a fruitiness that reminds me of sour-apples, a distinct grapefruit note in the finish.  The finish has a long, lingering, sort of cotton mouth astringency to it from both the oak and phenolic notes.  This is musty flavored but not as strongly so as in the aroma; musky, Brettanomyces notes, and some old sweat soaked blanket notes are found here as well.

My second pour is still as carbonated as the first.  I get to drinking this much sooner than my first pour and this literally explodes as it hits my tongue with a aggressive effervescent that turns the beer into foam as it rolls across my tongue.  The grapefruit note starts to come out more as it warms, some Klockera perhaps, and there seems to be a nice toasted oak character to the finish now as well.  Other fruit notes of ripe, but unsweet, quite aromatic, tart melon and perhaps a touch of pear also become more apparent as this warms and actually turn into quite the juicy fruit character.

I am so glad that my bottle has been cleaned of all the diacetyl that has been troubling some peoples bottles.  Pediococcus is a prodigious diacetyl producer and Lambics definitely need time to reduce it back out.  I am so glad that this turned out to be quite tasty.  Man this is quite good, about as tart / sour as I could want with just enough funkiness to keep things interesting.  This is a fantastic example of a Gueuze, at least this particular bottle is; if you are too worried just hold on to these for a 6 months or so (perhaps the international shipping helped my bottles).

Flavour is acidic, sour apples, a hint of sweetness, bit of cardboard and wood. Way too sour for me, but this got more enjoyable after a few sips. Still not something Id go for though.
Classic old basement aroma.  Dusty and lemony.  Superbly balanced flavor, not scorchingly sour.  This is one to lay down.  Many thanks to my gracious host, you know who you are!

Bottle at WSF. Pours golden coloured with a thick and dense egg white head. Floral aroma with notes of mustard, leather and grass. Tart and dry flavour with notes of malt, almonds and a little wood. Soft and mild gueuze, not that sour yet.

From bottle at Bierpassie weekend, Antwerpen. Cloudy golden with a small head. Complex acidic nose, promising lemon and citrus fruit above all. Wonderful acidic citrus flavours, still managing to keep the acid attack rather toned down. rather more mellow than Cantillon, closer to Drie Fonteinen. A one-off that will become a collectors item.
Bottled at PBF.  hazy deep golden, lively head. Strong barnyard aroma. Citric and fresh. Very lively Lightly vinegary with plwnty of hay and barnyard. Lovely and complex. As good as youd expect.

A Mes rate. Bottle at home. An awesome orange gold colour with an excellent white head. Funk yes. Some sweaty notes. Slight dia. Actually, no. VERY buttery. I think this will be really interesting at some point but right now, its clearly too young. Drinks more like a lambic than a blend. The longer its open the more its opening up. Far too young but once the bugs have eaten the diacetyl this should be splendid, although not for very long I would expect. Just the right spice and fruit. So hard to tell the individual characteristics. A great piece of blending. Hats off to Frank for a unique and intriguing event.

Bottled (PBF, vintage 2009, BB 10/2028, #14308). 
A bit hazy orange color, small white head. Tart grapefruity-fruity aroma. Tart, fruity flavor, a bit sweeter than eg. Cantillon geueze. Spitzy carbonation, Very tasty.

(Bottled, 0.75l) Opaque orange with a smallish, firm head. Very citric-fruity, tart aroma with strawberry. Flavor is also very fruity and dry with moderate acidity with some berry notes. Medium body, dry and astringent palate, slightly fizzy carbonation. A very successful and pleasant blend, IMO.
Hazy dark orange color with a foamy head. Seems a bit strangely simple for such a complex brew. Quite sour and really tart. Lots of tart citrus, lemon, peel and finishes dry. Really prickly sour.

Bottle that I picked up at Dranken Geers, Belgium consumed in garden 25-06-09   Pours orange/amber white head, quite hazy. Lemony nose, bit of dusty old furniture, slight sharpness, fruity. Taste is more of the same but the lemon is quite punchy, not as sharp as expected but nice, maybe 3-4 years on this will be even better? Likeable beer though, which went down well on a summers evening.  A7 A3 F7 P4 Ov15  3.6

Golden and hazy.  Slight hint of poo and overall a fairly spicy aroma.  Quite fizzy, herbal and chinotto-like bitterness with light pale malts.  Sort of an earthy finish.  Quite boon-like and not really my pocket of gueuze.

Bottle @ WSF. Slight haze, golden-amber and some fizzy bubbles. Sweet fruity aroma. Gentle carbonation. Nice, sweet, and hammy in places but tart and pithy in others. Generally good and lovely.

Generously shared by OSCF at his gathering - thanks, Todd! P00tz took more than his share of this, but I still got a healthy sampling of this funky brew. Cantillon must have been sick the day the blended this one. Pale orange pour with cloudy sediment and some pretty nice carbonation, a nice layer of foam sitting on top. This sharp nose tells you that the young lambics are dominating right now, and thats certainly evident in the mouth-puckering taste too. Funky and tart as hell, I wonder what this one will be like in a couple years.

Thanks todd for sharing. Pours a light hazy yellow with a one finger white head. The nose is strong, tart, nice barnyard/yeasty character, less subdued than some geuzes. The flavor is tart, appley, nice acidity, funky, nice yeasty flavors, will be great with a year or two more on it.

Thanks to Toodmister for this!  I think P00tz summed it up best : aroma of musty armpits and old sponge.  Tart citric acid with notable oaky hints and leather. A little sweet currently, still very nice with some excellent aging potential

P00Tz is baaaaaaaaack!!!  Smells musty armpits, old sponges, lemon, some light sourness.  This is a pretty good lambic shared by the Toddmister.  P00Tz  likes.   the P00tzster is still getting used to this style but could use more exposure. Yet again P00tzs beer life shares similarities with his woman life. First P00tz needs more stout women and then P00tz needs more stout beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2010 75cl bottle @ WSF. Bottle # 3053. Pours a cloudy orange with a large fluffy foam. Tart cellar nose. A bit of sweet almond - very vague. Dry and crisp with a fine funky,  tart and woody bite. Still very young and its clear to see and feel the potential it has to develop. Hope to taste it again in a few years.
 Re-Rating June 2010 @ Ma Che Siete, Rome. Aged amazingly. More sour, complex and tart. From 3,8 - 4,1

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 Cloudy orange with a big and lasting white head. Aroma of funky leather and grapefruit, hay, flowers and berries. Dry and somewhat malty flavour. Its tart, but not very sour yet. Great with potential to be even better. The bottle in my cellar will be for 2012 or there about. 9-3-8-3-15
At Ma Che Siete Venuti a Fa, RBESG 2010. Lots of complex funk and some wooden notes in the aroma. Dry and tart with grapefruit and funk. 
RBESG August 2011, grand tasting. 2011 bottle. Noticed a lot of pineapple character this time around. Quite fruity. 8-3-8-4-16 this time.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2016 Corked 2009 bottle, back label from Lindemans. Orange blonde color. Citrus, oak, leather and honey in the aroma. Sour, but also a very fruity geuze with grapefruit, pineapple, tangerine and lemon. Notes of oak and honey. Already a good complexity, still a bit rough at the edges. I thoroughly enjoyed this one.

Corked 2013 bottle, back label from Boon. Golden color. Oak, citrus, peach and honey in the aroma. Sour flavor with lemon and oak. Pineapple, tangerine and honey. Gooseberries. Moderately sour, Easy drinker. Still quite complex. Loved this one. (8 4 8 4 16 = 4.0)

Corked 2011 bottle, tasted July 2014. Oraneg golden color. lemon, oak and zuurtjes in the aroma. Sour flavor with lemon, oak, pineapple, peppermint. Surprisingly short aftertaste. Not as deep and complex as you might expect, but indeed a very nice lambic. ( 8 4 9 4 16 = 4.1)


Corked 2015 Bottle, Tasted december 2015. Golden color. Oak, grapefruit, confit fruit and pineapple in the aroma. Sour flavor with lemon, honey and pineapple. Lots of carbon. Oak especially noticeable in the finish. Well blended, complex geuze that perhaps needs more time. (8 4 8 4 16)

Cloudy amber with a large white head. Aroma had brett along with barnyard, brett, wood, and eather. Sour flavour with lacto, brett, malty and funky notes. Finished sour., Had a bit of wood to it. Though a bit young I liked it!
750ml bottle, courtesty mj? Pours cloudy light orange with a white head. Light aroma, of funky apple. Light-ish body and medium carbonation. Taste is difficult to describe.  Lightly sour finish.

Sweet fruit aroma with oak and barnyard. Cloudy, yellow colour, off-white head, good lace. Sweet, sour, bitter, oak, leather. Smooth and sparkling. Well balanced Geuze.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2011 Megablend  2009  version <Timmermans label, but all beer is blended @ F. Boon  Towering off-white head; hazy ochre-copper beer. Tart, grapey nose with overpowering horseblanket, spent grain, leathergrease and lunaria. Sweetish, grapey again, and Im getting old cheesy hops. Finish is drier. Fuller bodied than most gueuzes, with sourness coming as an afterthought, with again hops coming up in the very aftertaste. Surprising beer, just a bit different, but well-worth looking for.

Megablend 2011 version - beer is totally different from the 2009 version IMO 
Small white head, rather stable over hazy old dried straw-coloured beer. 4/5 Citrus, green apple, Bretts, saddlesoap, unripe lemons and kafir limes  9/10 Very tart, lactic acid, outspokenly citrussy and, nearly as an afterthought, the leather/saddlesoap flavour. Yet very balanced.  10/10 Tart, lipsmacking acidity, no trace of acetic acid, slightly liming. 4/5 Wow - a huge improvement compared to the first Megablend. This ranks amongs the true topgueuzes available.  19/20

Bottle many thanks to mes, at mess gaff with harry. Alround rating: Buttery sweetness, 3Fs appley dryness, boons house character, lindemans dicetyl character, some strange peppery character that iv had from de cam before. Its still probably not sorted itself out in the bottle yet, but my opening feelings are that theres too much boon and 3F in here.
Bottle.  Pours a copper body with a white head.  Honey, lemon, sour, vegetative with some light gueuze like funkiness.  Balsamic notes with a moderate acidity.  Not a great blend but a good beer.

750 ml bottle shared by Tertons!  Forgot the # but was in the 12,000s and didnt take note of its back label to determine where it came from.   Pours a deep gold with lively carbonation already - high for a new gueuze, and a frothy white head dissipates a bit- fizzy.  Aroma is moderate funk, orange peel, pez candy, mineral, chalk, earth, slight DMS and vegetal, with old and new wood, and hints of salty brine- good seems a bit clean.  Flavor has some weird earthy and solvent funk, lightly horsey citrus, lemon zest, slight salty notes, olive- light DMS leather, mineral and earth.  Finish is prickly light to moderate acidic, not overly sour at all, woody astringency and hints of grapefruit in the end as it warms.  Pretty good overall, a bit strange and different and with its subtle strange funk character it remains overall fairly clean still.  Not sure how this will age- at least maybe some of the DMS may fade a bit.

Thanks C. Really Good.  Hazy orange in color with a nice off white frothy head. Barnyard, citrusy, hoppy aroma.  Peppery notes. Moderately tart orangey bretty flavor. Dry hoppy finish. Well balanced and very drinkable.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2014 Bottle (750ml).  At MesandSims, London May 10 2009).  Cloudy orange, bubbly, with an average diminishing off-white frothy head.  Odd smell here - buttery diacetyl, odd in a lmabic - but underlying is a decent sweet caramel malt and lemony yeast aroma.  The taste, well, its getting there - this is quite young for a lambic, and it shows - aggressive sour lemon, sweet malt, neither have mellowed toward each other much yet, and its way too carbonated..  Fizzy, sticky mouthfeel, with a very quick finish - theres no big funky linger, not a lot of acdici yeasty goodness to remind you of mister toads lambic ride.  We all agreed that this might, with some aging, develop into a pretty solid sour, but right now its pretty green, with no depth or character.   Oh yeah - when the corked was popped, we thought it was going to gush all over the place, but it never did.  ** re-rated with a 2011 bottle on January 31, 2014 - original rating from 2009 was 6-3-7-3-13=3.2 ... this was much smoother, less aggressive, quite pleasant and a solid sour.

Bottle  Orange to amber body/  Frothy white head.  Quite weak aroma of barnyard and some citrus.  Moderately sour, moderately bitter flavour.  Not complex at all, even quite flat.  Not that interesting (at this point).
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2015 75cl, Vintage 2015, exclusive collab. brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex sour brew, balanced, hazy, good head, very good and original brew, yet expensive!

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Bottle # 08210. Pours a hazy amber golden with an off-white head leaving some lacework. Subtle tart aroma with some horse blanket touches. Medium body, astringent raw Bretty accents and vinegar, plenty of horse blanket. Rather sulphurous. Very Belgian in its sourness, but perhaps still a little young and raw. 010509

#36 - Amerikaner Blind-Smagning 01-Maj-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. Cloudy amber - white head. Sweetness, honey, caramel, brett, carrot, peppery, horsey, barnyard, light acid, earthy, light cheese, light citrus. Nice.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2012 750ml bottle.  Muddy orange colored body, off-white head.  Apples and solvent in the first whiff of the nose.  Buttered bran bread and solvent, what gives?  Semi-fizzy texture.  Baked apples and truffle oil.   Butter and solvent is far too heavy in the nose.  Difficult to like.  I dont know what else to say.


Rerate a couple of weeks later isnt so bad - more plain/bland/stale than solvent-like and spoiled.  Still not a great geuze my any means, but at least better than my first impression.  Rating upped from 2.7 to 3.1

From multiple bottles during Toer de Geuze. As we were told several times, its still a bit young. Pours a nice bright orange color with tight geometric bubbling. Tangy grapefruit nose is a little musty but mostly pretty clean. Tart flavor throughout with a little noticeable bitterness. Good sparkling mouthfeel and pretty dry on the finish. Pretty classy and refreshing overall, although not as complex as you might expect given its complicated parentage.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 #36 at papsø blind tasting
cloudy yellow, small white head.
ar:nice brett, slight citrussy, stable.
flavor:citrussy, well blended balance between citrussy and stable. very nice brew.

Bottle #36 at Papsøs blindtasting.
Hazy amber coloured with a medium sized white head.
Light acidic aroma of barnyard and hops
Light acidc flavour of barnyard, brett and hops.
Tart and hoppy finish.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2009 From bottle,  #08210, Papsoes blindtasting #36. Pours hazy orange with a huge white head. Dry brett-ish aroma. Orange fruity aroma too. Dry brett-ish flavoured, orange leather and slight vinegar. Dry, citric and orange fruity into the finish. Citric into the far finish.

#36
Bottle. [Papsoe grand American tasting] Large thick creamy off-white head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Cloudy golden color. Aroma of leather, barnyard, fruit, vinegar. Full bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sour flavor with good counter sweetness. Lingering sour fruity finish. 7 / 4 / 8 / 4 / 16 = 3.9
